title: How to Make a Harvey Wallbanger

steps.headline: Fill a glass with ice cubes.
steps.description: A Harvey Wallbanger is traditionally served in a highball glass, but any glass that holds between 1 and 1 ½ cups (240 and 350 ml) will work. Add enough ice to the glass to fill it nearly all the way to the top.

steps.headline: Add the vodka and orange juice.
steps.description: Pour 1 ½ ounces (44 ml) of vodka and 4 ounces (118 ml) of orange juice into the glass with the ice. Use a long cocktail spoon to stir the ingredients together well.

steps.headline: Float the Galliano on top.
steps.description:
Galliano is the star of a Harvey Wallbanger. Instead of mixing it in with the vodka and orange juice, though, hold a cocktail spoon upside down over the glass. Slowly pour the Galliano over the spoon and on top of the drink so it “floats.”
By using the spoon, you slow down the Galliano as it streams into the glass, so it doesn’t splash down into the vodka and orange mixture and mix in.

steps.headline: Garnish the cocktail with an orange slice and serve.
steps.description: Take an orange wedge or slice, and press it onto the rim of the glass. Serve the Harvey Wallbanger while it’s still chilled.

steps.headline: Heat the water and sugar until the sugar dissolves.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (100 g) of sugar and 1 cup (240 ml) of water to a small saucepan. Place the pan on the stove over medium heat, and allow it to cook down until the sugar dissolves, which should take about 5 to 7 minutes. Stir the mixture continuously as it heats to help the sugar dissolve and keep it from burning onto the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Remove the pan from the heat and add the vanilla bean.
steps.description: When the sugar has dissolved, take the pan off the stove. Drop 1 vanilla bean that’s been split down the middle with a knife into the syrup.

steps.headline: Cover the pot and allow the bean to steep in the syrup for 4 hours.
steps.description: Place the lid on the saucepan, and leave it to sit out on the counter at room temperature. Let the bean soak in the syrup for several hours to fully infuse it with the vanilla flavor.

steps.headline: Strain the syrup and bottle it.
steps.description: When the vanilla has steeped in the syrup for several hours, pour the syrup through a fine mesh sieve to strain it. Discard the vanilla bean, and transfer the syrup to an airtight container. Store it in the refrigerator for up to a week. You only need ½ ounce (15 ml) of vanilla syrup for the Harvey Wallbanger, so you’ll have enough vanilla syrup for about 15 cocktails.

steps.headline: Place the tea bag in the boiling water and steep for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Place a single bag of orange tea in a large mug. Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of boiling water over the tea, and allow the bag to soak until the water is fully brewed.

steps.headline: Remove the bag and allow the tea to cool completely.
steps.description: Take the tea bag out of the mug and discard it. Let the tea sit out on the counter for about 20 to 30 minutes or until it cools completely. You only need 2 ½ ounces (74 ml) of the brewed orange tea for the cocktail, so you’ll have enough for about 3 cocktails.

steps.headline: Peel a strip of orange zest and wrap it around the inside of the glass.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife or vegetable peeler to carefully remove a long strip of the skin from a fresh orange. Carefully place the zest inside a highball glass so it winds around the perimeter to serve as a garnish.

steps.headline: Fill the glass with ice.
steps.description: Once the orange zest is in place inside the glass, carefully add enough ice inside the peel to fill the glass nearly to the top. When you’re done, set the glass aside for the moment.

steps.headline: Add the vodka, Galliano, syrup, juice, and tea to a mixing glass.
steps.description: Fill the mixing glass to the top with ice. Next, pour 1 ½ ounces (44 ml) of vodka, ¾ ounce (22 ml) of Galliano, ½ ounce (15 ml) of the vanilla syrup,  ¼ ounce (7 ml) of fresh lemon juice, and 2 ½ ounces (74 ml) of the brewed orange tea.

steps.headline: Stir the mixture until well chilled.
steps.description: Stick a long cocktail spoon into the mixing glass, and mix it well. Continue stirring until the mixture is cold, which should take about 20 seconds.

steps.headline: Strain the cocktail into the prepared glass and serve.
steps.description: Use a cocktail strainer to pour the cocktail into the highball glass over the ice. Enjoy the Harvey Wallbanger while it’s still cold.

text:
Preparing a Classic Harvey Wallbanger Fill a glass with ice cubes. A Harvey Wallbanger is traditionally served in a highball glass, but any glass that holds between 1 and 1 ½ cups (240 and 350 ml) will work. Add enough ice to the glass to fill it nearly all the way to the top. Add the vodka and orange juice. Pour 1 ½ ounces (44 ml) of vodka and 4 ounces (118 ml) of orange juice into the glass with the ice. Use a long cocktail spoon to stir the ingredients together well. Float the Galliano on top. Galliano is the star of a Harvey Wallbanger. Instead of mixing it in with the vodka and orange juice, though, hold a cocktail spoon upside down over the glass. Slowly pour the Galliano over the spoon and on top of the drink so it “floats.”
By using the spoon, you slow down the Galliano as it streams into the glass, so it doesn’t splash down into the vodka and orange mixture and mix in. Garnish the cocktail with an orange slice and serve. Take an orange wedge or slice, and press it onto the rim of the glass. Serve the Harvey Wallbanger while it’s still chilled. Mixing an Upgraded Harvey Wallbanger Heat the water and sugar until the sugar dissolves. Add 1 cup (100 g) of sugar and 1 cup (240 ml) of water to a small saucepan. Place the pan on the stove over medium heat, and allow it to cook down until the sugar dissolves, which should take about 5 to 7 minutes. Stir the mixture continuously as it heats to help the sugar dissolve and keep it from burning onto the bottom of the pan. Remove the pan from the heat and add the vanilla bean. When the sugar has dissolved, take the pan off the stove. Drop 1 vanilla bean that’s been split down the middle with a knife into the syrup. Cover the pot and allow the bean to steep in the syrup for 4 hours. Place the lid on the saucepan, and leave it to sit out on the counter at room temperature. Let the bean soak in the syrup for several hours to fully infuse it with the vanilla flavor. Strain the syrup and bottle it. When the vanilla has steeped in the syrup for several hours, pour the syrup through a fine mesh sieve to strain it. Discard the vanilla bean, and transfer the syrup to an airtight container. Store it in the refrigerator for up to a week. You only need ½ ounce (15 ml) of vanilla syrup for the Harvey Wallbanger, so you’ll have enough vanilla syrup for about 15 cocktails. Place the tea bag in the boiling water and steep for 5 minutes. Place a single bag of orange tea in a large mug. Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of boiling water over the tea, and allow the bag to soak until the water is fully brewed. Remove the bag and allow the tea to cool completely. Take the tea bag out of the mug and discard it. Let the tea sit out on the counter for about 20 to 30 minutes or until it cools completely. You only need 2 ½ ounces (74 ml) of the brewed orange tea for the cocktail, so you’ll have enough for about 3 cocktails. Peel a strip of orange zest and wrap it around the inside of the glass. Use a sharp knife or vegetable peeler to carefully remove a long strip of the skin from a fresh orange. Carefully place the zest inside a highball glass so it winds around the perimeter to serve as a garnish. Fill the glass with ice. Once the orange zest is in place inside the glass, carefully add enough ice inside the peel to fill the glass nearly to the top. When you’re done, set the glass aside for the moment. Add the vodka, Galliano, syrup, juice, and tea to a mixing glass. Fill the mixing glass to the top with ice. Next, pour 1 ½ ounces (44 ml) of vodka, ¾ ounce (22 ml) of Galliano, ½ ounce (15 ml) of the vanilla syrup,  ¼ ounce (7 ml) of fresh lemon juice, and 2 ½ ounces (74 ml) of the brewed orange tea. Stir the mixture until well chilled. Stick a long cocktail spoon into the mixing glass, and mix it well. Continue stirring until the mixture is cold, which should take about 20 seconds. Strain the cocktail into the prepared glass and serve. Use a cocktail strainer to pour the cocktail into the highball glass over the ice. Enjoy the Harvey Wallbanger while it’s still cold.
